{{Infobox artwork | title = Statue of James Outram |italic title= no | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image_file = Statue of James Outram, Victoria Embankment Gardens.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = The statue in 2015 | artist = [[Matthew Noble]] | catalogue = | year = {{start date|1871}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | type = Sculpture | material = [[Bronze sculpture|Bronze]] | subject = | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | condition = | city = London, United Kingdom | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{coord|51.50630|-0.12309|format=dms|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | owner = | url = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} The '''statue of [[Sir James Outram, 1st Baronet|James Outram]]''', a work by [[Matthew Noble]], stands on [[Victoria Embankment Gardens]] in [[London]], south of [[Hungerford Bridge]].<ref>{{cite news|title=London: By the river of memory|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/729112/London-By-the-river-of-memory.html|accessdate=31 May 2015|work=The Telegraph|date=8 November 2003}}</ref> It is a [[Grade II listed]] structure.
Unusually, the plan to erect the statue began in Outram's own lifetime, at a public meeting held in Willis's Rooms, London, on 5 March 1861. The general had recently returned to Britain from [[British Raj|India]], the stage on which his military career had been played out, due to poor health. It was decided to erect an equestrian monument in [[Kolkata|Calcutta]], with [[John Henry Foley|J. H. Foley]] as the sculptor, and a standing design by Matthew Noble in London, "near [[Statue of Henry Havelock, Trafalgar Square|[the statue]]] of his illustrious comrade, Sir [[Henry Havelock]]", on [[Trafalgar Square]]. Permission for this site was refused by the First Commissioner of Works, who subsequently offered a site in the yet-to-be-created Embankment Gardens. The statue was unveiled by [[Charles Wood, 1st Viscount Halifax|Lord Halifax]], a former [[Secretary of State for India]], on 17 August 1871.<ref>{{citation | ref = harv | last = Ward-Jackson | first = Philip | year = 2011 | title = Public Sculpture of Historic Westminster: Volume 1 | series = Public Sculpture of Britain | volume = 14 | location = Liverpool | publisher = Liverpool University Press | pages = 308–10 }}</ref>
The bronze statue rests on a granite pedestal.<ref>{{cite book|title=Old and new London: a narrative of its history, its people and its places|date=1880|page=328|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lekHAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA328&lpg=PA328&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=31 May 2015|first1=George Walter|last1=Thornbury|first2=Edward|last2=Walford}}</ref>
